title: Woman transforms cars with hand-drawn designs
description:
(1 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
An Egyptian woman is forging a creative niche in the normally male-dominated automotive industry.
Sara Diab decorates Cairo's cars with unique, hand-drawn designs.
STORYLINE:
Sara Diab is transforming an ordinary silver car into something special.
She's using her artistic talent to decorate its wing mirrors and bonnet.
The intricate patterns she carefully draws on the paint work are her own design.
Diab is an archaeology graduate but has been working in this unusual job for the last two years.
"I first started with a small drawing on one of my friend's cars and he really liked it. Then I started sharing my drawing designs on my Facebook page. And lots of users loved them," she says.
The artist doesn't work from a studio. Instead, she rents a space at a car wash and clients bring their vehicles here for her to work on.
The designs can take one or two weeks to complete and the price varies according to the complexity of the pattern.
And Diab makes sure she uses the right materials so all that hard work and money doesn't go to waste.
"My drawings can not be removed from the car's body, even by water or washing with soap," she says.
This design has taken a week to complete.
Its owner, Abd Allah Hossam, has opted for a striking all-black pattern.
He found Diab's work on Facebook and spent some time discussing ideas with her before they agreed on the final plan for his car.
"She showed me what she can do from her designs and I showed her other designs as well. And we managed to finish my car today," he says.
Not all designs are as discreet as the one adorning Allah Hossam's vehicle.
This vivid pink and purple pattern was completed three months ago.
Its proud owner comes to the car wash twice a month to keep the car looking its best.
The eye-catching design draws regular compliments.
"A lot of people stop me in the street to ask about the design as it is a new idea and not a lot of people have their cars made like this," says the owner, Amir Kamal. 
A lot of vehicles in Egypt are covered in stickers to decorate the body work.
But Diab insists her hand-drawn method is superior.
"The sticker is found everywhere and is imprinted directly on the car. But the drawing is unique," she says.
 "There must be a difference because every drawing has its own soul."
With the day's drawing done, the young designer heads home.
This work provides money to cover her financial outgoings for now. 
But she would consider leaving it behind for a stable job or a new business idea.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/e73dfb36fbad144d4e2d27fe764edbf4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
